results.title: The Tail
results.creator_credit: Yung Ting Lao and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
Amusing 2-D and 3-D computer animated tale about tails and their eventual destination as trophies on a wall. No dialogue.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.

results.title: The Ta Ching pioneers
results.brief_description: An insight into the founders of the Ta Ching oil fields and its present development. Produced under the direction of Chairman Mao, suppressed by the “Gang of Four” then re-released.

results.title: The Syrian Civil Defence
results.brief_description: Hospitals under siege, constant firefights, the Syrian Civil Defence sifting through bombed buildings. Millions of videos of the Syrian Civil War have been recorded and uploaded to YouTube and online platforms, but has all this footage made any difference?

results.title: The Symphony sound with Henry Lewis: introduction to the performing arts
results.creator_credit: William Francisco, Robert Saudek, Learning Corporation of America and Robert Saudek Associates
results.brief_description: Henry Lewis discusses the unique characteristics of the symphony orchestra, and describes the instruments and their particular roles within the symphony. Mr Lewis conducts the orchestra in examples from many periods and composers.

results.title: The Symphony orchestra
results.brief_description: The composer who creates symphonic music must still rely on the efforts of many other musicians for a performance of his work; and the conductor of the orchestra which is to perform a symphonic work is largely responsible for the interpretation placed on the work of the composer whose work they are to play. In this film, the function of the various choirs of the orchestra is demonstrated, as Howard Barlow conducts the Columbia Symphony Orchestra in a performance of Wagner’s “Ride of the Valkyries” and the Prelude to Act III of “Lohengrin”.
results.description: The composer who creates symphonic music must still rely on the efforts of many other musicians for a performance of his work; and the conductor of the orchestra which is to perform a symphonic work is largely responsible for the interpretation placed on the work of the composer whose work they are to play. results.title: The Symphonie experiment: a report
results.creator_credit: French Telecommunication Research Center and Unesco
results.brief_description: 36,000 kilometres above the Equator, the French/German satellite ‘Symphonie’ circles the earth. The two governments offered their satellite to UNESCO on an experimental basis for its 19th General Conference, held at Nairobi, Kenya. The film details the facilities made available, and the consequent benefits to UNESCO and the world.
results.description: 36,000 kilometres above the Equator, the French/German satellite ‘Symphonie’ circles the earth. results.title: The Sydney Opera House Tenth Anniversary Recital: Roger Woodward
results.creator_credit: Peter Skillman, Peter Abbott and Yoho Productions
results.brief_description: Roper Woodward played the first recital at the Sydney Opera House in 1973 and ten years later he was given the honour of performing the tenth anniversary recital on October 1, 1983. This video presents Roger Woodward performing the commemorative tenth recital live at the Sydney Opera House playing three of Beethoven’s sonatas and ending with an encore of Chopin’s Grand Waltz.

results.title: The Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras Parade
results.creator_credit: Stephen Jones, Susan Oliver and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: In 1994 the ABC chose to broadcast the annual Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras Parade live on Australian television. The decision generated much controversy but the public broadcasting of the event allowed all Australians to witness the joy and imagination involved in what is now one of the world’s leading festivals. This video of the broadcast includes footage not shown on the original screening. The Mardi Gras is a street festival in which lesbians, gays, queers and deviants can celebrate their communities and their determination to not be hidden from the public face of Australian culture. The theme of the 1994 Mardi Gras was “We Are Family” which aptly defines the strength of the Australian gay and lesbian movements in forging new forms of communal relationships which are working to challenge and destabilise homophobia. Testament to the Parade’s success is its ability to bring almost a million people onto the streets of Sydney to join in the celebrations.

results.title: The Sydney Dance Company in Daphnis & Chloe
results.creator_credit: Jolyon Wimhurst, Charles Thompson, Channel 4 Television Corporation and Independent Film Channel (US)
results.brief_description: The program opens with the choreographer, Graeme Murphy, discussing the origins of the work and how he changed it, illustrated with extracts from the performance which follows. The performance opens in a garden which is overseen by the God Pan. Innocent Daphnis falls for Chloe, but he has a rival, Dorcan the Herdsmen. They vie for her hand in a dance competition; the winner to receive a kiss.
